children.text: Content Literacy
Interpret what is read through illustrations.
Listen to stories to gain information on a main idea.
Identify vocabulary through illustrations.
Listen to text for main ideas.
Listen for main idea and sequence of events in a social studies context.
Use vocabulary in sentences.
Identify fact and opinion.
Use reading and writing to respond to literature.
Identify graphic organizers as a way of organizing information.
Use pre-reading to skim text for main ideas.
Identify main idea and sequence of events in a social studies context.
Increase comprehension using graphic organizers.
Use content specific vocabulary in sentences.
Skim text for main ideas.
Identify main idea, sequence of events, and cause and effect in a social studies context.
Use reading and writing to respond to historical literature.
Increase comprehension through notes and graphic organizers.
Use reading strategies to identify key content words, and supporting details to build comprehension.
Identify cause and effect and fact v. opinion.
Gather information making outlines, and creating graphic organizers.
Read texts by using reading strategies (i.e., prior knowledge, key vocabulary words, context clues, main ideas, supporting details, and text features: pictures, maps, text boxes).
Read to identify cause and effect relationships, compare and contrast information, fact v. opinion, and author bias.
Apply reading and writing strategies to construct and express knowledge.
Gather information by taking notes, making outlines, and creating graphic organizers.
Formulate essential questions on a given topic.
Read texts by using reading strategies (i.e., prior knowledge, identify key vocabulary words, context clues, main ideas, supporting details, and text features: pictures, maps, text boxes).
Read for a specific purpose (i.e., detect cause & effect relationships, compare & contrast information, identify fact v. opinion, and author bias).
Respond to historical texts and various types of social studies literature by inferring, drawing conclusions, making predictions, and formulating historic, geographic, economic, and civic questions.
Process or synthesize information through writing using note taking, graphic organizers, summaries, proper sequencing of events, and/or formulating thesis statements that examine why as well as how.
Information, Media & Technology Literacy
Gather information and present orally.
Identify maps, graphs, and charts.
Use developmentally appropriate technology resources to support learning.
Research a given social studies topic.
Conduct research by locating, gathering, and organizing information.
Present information orally.
Identify maps, graphs, charts, diagrams as sources of information.
Practice responsible use of technology.
Use technology resources for problem solving, communication, and illustration of thoughts and ideas.
Present information orally or in writing.
Use maps, graphs, charts, diagrams.
Demonstrate positive social behaviors when using technology.
Read maps, graphs, charts, and diagrams for information.
Demonstrate positive social and ethical behaviors when using technology and discuss consequences of inappropriate use.
Use the technology to effectively access information.
Ask questions to identify a research topic.
Present information orally and in writing.
Create maps, graphs, charts, diagrams to demonstrate knowledge.
Use technology tools for individual and collaborative writing, communication, and publishing.
Use the technology to efficiently and effectively access information.
Conduct research by locating, gathering, and organizing information using online and print resources.
Present content orally, in writing, and through multimedia presentations.
Explain content through the use of maps, graphs, charts, diagrams.
Use content specific technology tools to support learning.
Evaluate the accuracy, relevancy, and bias of online, print, and media sources (teacher led).
Formulate appropriate research questions.
Conduct research by locating, gathering, organizing information and data, and evaluating online and print resources.
Effectively communicate and present information orally, in writing, and through the development of multimedia presentations, and other forms of technology.
Identify propaganda, censorship, and bias in the media.
Explain content through the use of maps, graphs, charts, and diagrams.
Use technology resources for problem solving, self-directed learning, and extended learning activities.
Use content specific technology tools to support learning and research.
Evaluate the accuracy, relevancy, appropriateness, and bias of online and print sources.
Conduct research by gathering, organizing, and evaluating the credibility and bias of information from a variety of online, print, and non-print sources.
Process and effectively communicate and present information orally, in writing, and through development of web sites, multimedia presentations, and other forms of technology.
Critically analyze messages in the media to detect propaganda, censorship, and bias.
Create, interpret, analyze and detect bias in maps, graphs, charts, diagrams.
Demonstrate and advocate for legal and ethical behaviors among peers, family, and community regarding the use of technology.
Collaborate with peers, experts, and others to contribute to a content related knowledge base, e.g., use of blogs, wikis, podcasts, etc. to compile, synthesize, produce, and disseminate information.
Historical Analysis & Interpretation
Understand the concept of yesterday, today, and tomorrow.
Identify sources of information.
Listen to historical fiction.
Identify events of yesterday and today.
Read and/or listen to historical fiction.
Identify self perspective.
Demonstrate an understanding of chronology by reading a timeline.
Identify past, present, and future events.
Discuss appropriate sources of information.
Begin to identify differing perspectives.
Read and discuss historical fiction.
Demonstrate an understanding of chronology by recording events on a timeline.
Read tall tales/stories to enhance Nevada history.
Begin to discuss historical perspectives.
Demonstrate an understanding of chronology by creating and interpreting events on a timeline.
Identify and discuss primary and secondary sources.
Read tall tales/stories to enhance American history.
Discuss perspectives of history.
Develop a clear sense of historical time, past, present, and future in order to identify the sequence in which events occurred.
Identify primary and secondary sources as historical content.
Identify historical myths and historical fact.
Apply social studies (content & skills) to real life situations.
Formulate historical questions.
Interpret history through the use of primary and secondary sources.
Identify multiple perspectives of historical events.
Answer a historical question through the interpretation of primary sources.
Analyze patterns of historical continuity and change to demonstrate chronological thinking.
Analyze and evaluate primary and secondary sources for historical perspectives.
Differentiate between historical memory and historical fact.
Extract significant ideas from social studies sources and frame historical questions.
Use primary and secondary sources to analyze and interpret history.
Compare multiple perspectives of historical events, using a variety of sources.
Analyze and interpret primary sources to answer a historical question.
Civic Participation
Show responsibility for the well-being of oneself.
Listen and participate as a member of a group in the classroom.
Show responsibility for the well-being of oneself and family.
Participate as a member of the school community.
Accept responsibility for the well-being of oneself, family, and the community.
Identify issues and events that have an impact on people at local, state, national, and global levels.
Ask meaningful questions to evaluate information.
Use effective decision-making and problem-solving skills in public and private life.
Collaborate effectively as a member of a group.
Demonstrate responsibility for the well-being of oneself, family, and the community.
Discuss issues and events that have an impact on people at local, state, national, and global levels.
Actively participate in civic and community life at local, state, national, and global levels.
Seek information from varied sources and perspectives to develop informed opinions and creative solutions.
Ask meaningful questions and analyze and evaluate information and ideas.
Identify sources and perspectives that influence the formation of opinions and creative solutions.

text: Content Standard H1.0 - People, Cultures, and Civilizations - Students understand the development, characteristics, and interaction of people, cultures, societies, religion, and ideas.

children.text: United States & Nevada
Discuss the importance of working together to complete tasks.
Listen to stories of family members, local residents, and prominent figures to highlight the human experience.
Describe local life long ago, including jobs, school, communication, transportation, and recreation.
Listen to stories that reflect the beliefs, customs, ceremonies, and traditions of the varied cultures in the neighborhood.
Listen to histories of important local landmarks that create a sense of community among citizens.
Compare the local community with others around the nation.
Use artifacts to understand how people lived their daily lives.
Tell why important events, people, and/or customs are markby holidays.
Recognize similarities and differences of earlier generations in areas such as work, dress, manners, stories, games, and festivals.
Learn about individuals in the community and discuss their contributions.
Using artifacts and primary sources, and investigate how individuals and families contributed to the founding and development of the local community.
Describe the lifestyles of Nevada's Desert Archaic people.
Define hunter-gatherer.
Describe the lifestyles of Nevada's Native American cultures.
Discuss the interactions of pioneers with the Great Basin Indians.
Identify and describe Native North American life and cultural regions prior to European contact.
Identify and describe the attributes of Native American nations in the local region and North America.
Discuss the interactions of early explorers with native cultures.
Identify the contributions of Native Americans, Europeans, and Africans to North American beliefs and traditions.
Describe the social, political, and religious lives of people in the New England, Middle, and Southern colonies.
Transatlantic Encounters
Describe the cultural contributions of Native Americans in Nevada and in the United States.
Investigate ways in which Native Americans and immigrants helped create North American culture.
Describe the interactions among Native Americans, Europeans, and Africans.
Colonial America
Compare lifestyles in the New England, Middle, and Southern colonies as determined by race, class, and gender.
Antebellum America
Identify American industrialists and discuss their contributions to the social, economic, and political way of life.
Explain how literature, music, architecture, and visual arts were a reflection of each time period.
Westward Expansion
Explore the lure of the West and the reality of life on the frontier as it relates to communication, farming and water issues, mining, and ranching.
Describe the contributions of immigrant groups to the emerging American culture.
Discuss the characteristics of American culture.
Describe the role of farming, railroads, and mining in the settlement of the West.
World War I & World War II
Explain the effects of WWI and WWII on social and cultural life in Nevada and the United States.
The Gilded Age & the Progressive Era
Assess the impact of the Industrial Revolution on race, class, and gender.
Discuss the influences of American industrialists on the rise of corporate capitalism.
Assess the impact of technological innovations and urbanization on society's social and economic development.
Define nativism and explain the political and social responses to immigration into the United States.
Identify the causes and analyze the consequences of labor movements in the United States.
Explain how 20th century social movements led to the emergence of a pluralistic society.
The 1920's
Evaluate how cultural developments in the arts, literature, architecture, education, media, and leisure activities have reflected and changed society.
Discuss the effects of early technologies on society, i.e., communication, transportation, and manufacturing.
World
Listen to stories of people and families around the world.
Listen to stories that reflect the beliefs, customs, ceremonies, traditions, and social practices of cultures around the world.
Identify landmarks around the world.
Compare communities around the world with the local community.
Explain why important events, people, and/or customs from around the world are marked by holidays.
Examine artifacts from around the world for important clues as to how people lived their daily lives.
Learn about individuals around the world and discuss their contributions.
Identify contributions of immigrants in Nevada.
Identify individuals and groups responsible for founding and settling the American colonies.
Examine the cultural exchange among the Native Americans, Europeans, and Africans.
Pre-Civilization
Identify and describe the characteristics of pre-agricultural societies.
Identify and describe the technological innovations of early agrarian societies.
Identify the characteristics of pre-Columbian civilizations in South America that became part of American culture.
Evaluate factors that contributed to the fall of pre-Columbian civilizations.
Early Civilizations
Identify the characteristics of a civilization.
Explain how a civilization's geographic location influenced its development.
Describe the achievements of ancient and classical civilizations.
Locate ancient, classical, and regional civilizations and describe their contributions of social structure, religion, and political systems.
Describe the origin, traditions, customs, and spread of the five major world religions (Judaism, Christianity, Islam, Hinduism and Buddhism).
Describe the cultural achievements of societies in the Middle East, Far East, the Americas, Africa, South Asia, and Europe.
Middle Ages
Identify contributions of individuals around the world during the Middle Ages.
Explain the impact of the Crusades, trade, and the Plague on society during the Middle Ages.
Transatlantic Encounters
Explain how trade causes cultural diffusion.
Compare and contrast the characteristics of dominant world cultures.
Analyze how and why the five major religions gained new adherents in various parts of the world.
Renaissance, Reformation & the Enlightenment
Examine the impact of scientific, technological, mathematical, cultural, and artistic developments of the Renaissance on societies around the world.
Explain the causes of the Reformation and its effects in Europe and the Americas.
Identify the influence of the Enlightenment on the Western World, i.e., philosophy, science, fine arts, government, and literature.
Industrialization
Analyze the cultural, social, and economic changes that occurred as a result of industrialization.
Analyze how industrialization, migration, changing diets, and scientific and medical advances have affected worldwide demographics.

text: Content Standard H2.0 - Nation Building and Development - Students understand the people, events, ideas, and conflicts that lead to the evolution of nations, empires, distinctive cultures, and political and economic ideas.

children.text: United States & Nevada
Identify problems that occur when people live and work together.
Identify ways that sharing can resolve problems in the classroom and school.
Identify ways in which people cooperate to achieve a common goal.
Explore the importance of both local and national landmarks, and explain how they create a sense of community among citizens.
Discuss how conflicts can be resolved through compromise.
Explain how memorials help us to honor and remember people.
Discuss examples of compromise and conflict within Nevada, i.e., Pyramid Lake Wars, water allocation, Sagebrush Rebellion.
Describe the experiences of pioneers moving west.
Identify explorers and settlers in pre-territorial Nevada.
Identify the diverse population of Nevada's early settlers and discuss their unique experiences.
Explain the symbols, mottoes, and slogans related to Nevada, i.e., "Battle Born," the state seal, and "Silver State."
Describe motivations for and expeditions of European exploration of the Americas.
Describe issues of compromise and conflict within the United States.
Describe the competition among the English, French, Spanish, Dutch, and Indian nations for control of North America.
Explain why slavery was introduced into colonial America.
Explain how the interactions among Native Americans, Africans, and Europeans, during colonial America resulted in unique economic, social, and political institutions.
Identify the events that led to the Declaration of Independence.
Identify the causes, key events, and people of the American Revolution.
Nevada Statehood
Summarize the contributions of the diverse populations of Nevada's early settlers.
Explain the events that led to Nevada's statehood.
Describe how compromise and conflict among peoples contributed to political, economic, and cultural divisions.
Identify and explain the importance of immigrant and native groups to mining, ranching, railroads, and commerce in Nevada and the United States.
Describe the impact of the United States military and atomic testing on Nevada.
Describe the effects of tourism and gaming on Nevada.
Describe the goals and accomplishments of labor unions in Nevada.
Constitutional America
Determine the significance of the first and second Continental Congress and the Committees of Correspondence.
Describe the events, course, and results of the American Revolution, including the contributions of women, African Americans, and Native Americans.
Explain how the failures of the Articles of Confederation led to the creation of the Constitution.
Explain the issues involved in the creation and ratification of the U.S. Constitution and the new government it established.
Identify the individual and states rights protected by the Bill of Rights and their continuing significance.
Nationalism
Evaluate the influence of individuals in the building of a national identity, i.e., Pontiac, George Washington, and Abigail Adams.
Describe contributing factors in the development of a national identity following the War of 1812.
Describe the colonization, immigration, and settlement patterns of the American people, i.e., the role of economic incentives, the effects of physical/political geography, and transportation systems.
Westward Expansion
Define the concept of Manifest Destiny and explain the events that led to the expansion of the United States.
Discuss and analyze the interactions between pioneers and Native Americans during the westward expansion.
Civil War and Reconstruction
Describe the institutionalization of slavery in America, the resistance of the enslaved, and the ongoing struggle between proponents and opponents of slavery.
Identify and describe the causes, key people, and events of the Civil War.
Identify and discuss the immediate outcomes and long term effects of the Civil War.
Summarize the successes and failures of Reconstruction.
The Gilded Age & the Progressive Era
Describe the effects of industrialization and new technologies on the development of the United States.
The Great Depression
Explain the causes of the Great Depression and the impact the Great Depression had on society and its effect on U.S. political policy.
Revolutionary America
Summarize the concepts and results of the American Revolution and post revolutionary outcomes as they apply to the 20th Century.
Civil War & Reconstruction
Summarize the concepts and results of the Civil War and Reconstruction as they apply to the 20th Century.
Development of the West in the 19th Century
Analyze how different cultures, points of view, and self-interests influence compromise and conflict over territories, borders, and resources.
Describe the final settlement of the West and federal policy toward Native Americans, i.e., the Dawes Act, Plains Wars, and the reservation system.
Imperialism and World War I
Assess the contributions of immigrant groups to the development of the United States.
Define imperialism and discuss its impact on U.S. political relations with other nations.
Discuss the causes and consequences of U. S. policies regarding expansion and diplomacy.
Discuss the economic and political effects of World War I on the United States.
Great Depression & the New Deal
Describe the causes and consequences of the Great Depression.
Analyze the policies and programs of the New Deal, and their effects on political, economic, and diplomatic institutions.
World War II
Describe the cultural, economic, political, and technological impact of World War II on the United States.
The Cold War
Describe the causes and effects of changing demographics and developing suburbanization in the United States.
Explain the effects of Cold War policies on U.S. involvement in Korea and Vietnam.
Examine the changes in the political culture of the United States during the 1960's and 1970's, i.e., Assassination of JFK, Watergate, Iranian Hostage Crisis.
Contemporary Global Issues
Explain the economic, political, and technological impact of the following conflicts on the United States, i.e., Korea, Vietnam, Persian Gulf War, Iraq, and the War on Terror.
World
Explain how United States conflicts affected life and society in Nevada.
Explain the relationship between the American colonies and England, and discuss its impact on independence.
Early Civilizations
Identify the characteristics that led to the emergence and decline of empires around the world.
Identify the characteristics of various political systems of ancient civilizations.
Middle Ages
Explain how feudal relationships provided a foundation for political order in Europe and Japan.
Determine the causes and consequences of political revolutions.
Define nation states and explain their political development.
Exploration & Trade
Define mercantilism and explain how it influenced patterns of economic activity.
Explore how a desire for foreign goods led to an increase of economic and cultural diversity.
Empire Building
Examine the roles of nationalism, imperialism, and religion in the building and development of nations.
Describe the rise of commercial trading centers and their effects on social, political, and economic institutions around the world.
Explain the development of monarchies and their effects on centralized government, commerce and trade, and religion.
Explain how Greek and Roman civilizations influenced the development of democratic and republican governments in modern societies.
Analyze the development of the nation state and explain how nation states differ from empires or other forms of political organizations.
World War I & World War II
Explain why and how global power shifts took place after World War I and World War II.
Explain how the break-up of the Soviet Union and other Eastern European communist governments led to the formation of new nations.
Contemporary Global Issues
Explain the objectives of various independence movements and analyze the political factors that contributed to the change of a nation.
Discuss examples of contemporary ethnic conflicts and explain how those conflicts have changed nations.
Discuss major reasons for tensions and conflicts in the contemporary world and efforts that have been made to address them.

text: Content Standard H3.0 - Social Responsibility & Change - Students understand how social ideas and individual action lead to social, political, economic, and technological change.

children.text: United States & Nevada
Recognize differences between home and school.
Describe the importance of working together to complete tasks.
Identify the occupations of people in their school.
Demonstrate respect for each other in the classroom and school.
Describe the neighborhood around their school.
Compare and/or contrast their daily lives with those of their parents or guardians.
Identify and describe occupations in the community that help people, i.e., police officers, fire fighters, and nurses.
Demonstrate respect for each other and people in the neighborhood.
Identify public and private spaces within the community.
Compare and/or contrast their daily lives with children around the world.
Explain why people and events are honored in commemorative holidays.
Demonstrate respect for each other and people in the community.
Define technology and identify uses of technology in their daily lives.
Explain how the actions of heroes and heroines make a difference.
Determine what it means to be an American citizen and describe the achievements of famous and ordinary citizens.
Define ethnicity and explain that people who make contributions to their communities include those who have diverse ethnic origins, customs, and traditions.
Demonstrate respect for each other, the community, and the world.
Explain how technology at home and in school impacts their lives.
Compare and/or contrast their daily lives with children in Nevada's past.
Recognize that communities include people who have diverse ethnic origins, customs, and traditions, and who make contributions to Nevada.
Define social responsibility.
Explain how advances in technologies have impacted Nevada, i.e., railroads, mining, and gaming.
Compare and/or contrast the daily lives of children throughout the United States, both past and present.
Recognize that communities include people who have diverse ethnic origins, customs, and traditions, and who make contributions to the United States.
Describe ways individuals display social responsibility.
Explain how technologies in U.S. history changed the way people lived.
American Revolutionary Era
Describe the similarities and differences of European colonial communities in North America in terms of politics, religion, language, economics, and social customs.
Explain the political and economic causes and effects of the American Revolution.
Describe key political ideas that influenced the American Revolution and the formation of the United States.
Explain the major ideas expressed in the Declaration of Independence.
Antebellum America
Describe the social reform and religious movements of antebellum America.
Define abolition and identify key people and events of the movement.
Explain the struggle between states' rights and federalism, and the impact on the national identity in the United States.
Explore the causes, events, major inventions, and technologies of the Industrial Revolution and explain their impact on the way of life in Nevada and the United States.
Reconstruction
Identify the 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments to the Constitution and explain their impact on the expansion of human rights.
Identify the Black Codes and Jim Crow Laws and explain how they reflected attitudes about race.
The Gilded Age & Progressive Era
Discuss the rise of the Populist and Progressive Movements and explain how they reflected social change.
Describe key people and explain their struggle for the expansion of African American rights during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
Describe the rise of corporations and analyze working conditions in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
Analyze the contributions of inventors and innovators that led to a change in society.
Determine the causes and effects of the Populist and Progressive Movements.
Analyze major social movements in the United States and explain their impact on the changing social and political culture, i.e., the Populist and Progressive Movements.
Explain the major social, technological, and cultural developments of the 1920's.
Examine social tensions in the post-World War I era, i.e., radical politics, immigration restrictions, internal migration, religious fundamentalism, and racism.
Describe the development of the women's suffrage movement and the subsequent passage of the 19th Amendment.
Civil Rights & the 1960's
Explain how the social and economic opportunities of the post-World War II era contributed to social responsibility and change.

Identify and describe the major issues, events, and people of minority rights movements, i.e., Civil Rights Act of 1964, Black Power Movement, United Farm Workers, American Indian Movement, Viva La Raza, and Women's Rights Movement.
Cold War
Analyze how post-World War II science and technology augmented United States economic strength, transformed daily life, and influenced the world economy and politics.
Compare and contrast the social impact of the Cold War and the War on Terror on the United States.
World
Share events that are important to the students and their families.
Discuss events that are happening at the school.
Listen to and discuss news events in the community.
Discuss the effects of news events on people in the community.
Discuss major news events on the local and state levels.
Provide and discuss major news events on local, state, national, and world levels.
Early Civilizations
Explain how democratic principles introduced by the Greeks and Romans developed the concept of social responsibility.
Analyze the social impact of technology, i.e., ships, iron, water delivery systems, wheel, and the printing press.
Explain the spread of the five major world religions and their impact on society.
Identify institutions of social responsibility and explain their impact on society, i.e., church, government, family.
Compare the economic and social importance of slavery with other forms of coerced labor from ancient times to the present.
Middle Ages
Explain how civilizations create order through social groupings, i.e., caste system, class system, feudalism.
The Modern World
Analyze how post-World War II science and technology augmented United States economic strength, transformed daily life, and influenced the world economy and politics.
Analyze major news events and their impact at the local, state, national, and world levels.
Compare and contrast racial segregation in the United States with other racial and social policies, i.e., apartheid in South Africa.
Explain the impact of the five major world religions on the world's political and social fabric.
Analyze the responses of individuals to restrictive social and political systems.
Analyze how ideals and institutions of freedom, equality, justice, and citizenship have changed.
Evaluate the worldwide implications of advancements in nuclear, electronic, and computer and medical technologies.
Explain how literature, music, and art are ways people voice protest or support, and prompt social change.
Determine the causes and consequences of genocidal conflicts, i.e., the Holocaust, Armenia, Bosnia, Rwanda, and Darfur.
Analyze the causes, consequences, and moral implications of ethnic conflicts around the world.
Explain the changing role of race, class, and gender.
Explain how literature, music, media, and the visual arts affect social change.
Examine the ideals and institutions of freedom, equality, justice, and citizenship, and explain how they have changed.
Understand how border disputes reflected and influenced peoples' conceptions of identity.

text: Content Standard H4.0 - International Relationships & Power - Students understand the interaction and interdependence of nations around the world. Students understand the impact of economics, politics, religion, and culture on international relationships.

children.text: United States & Nevada
Colonial America
Describe major local, national, and world issues; and explain their impact on international relations.
Describe the causes and effects of the French and Indian War on U.S. political policy and the expansion of U.S. territory.
American Revolutionary Era
Describe the influence of the American Revolution on Europe and the Americas.
Describe the contributions of foreign individuals and nations to the outcome of the American Revolution.
World War I & World War II
Examine U.S. involvement in World War I.
Explain the political and economic effects of World War I on the United States.
Identify the causes of World War II and the reasons for U.S. entry into the war.
Discuss the effects of World War II on American economic and political policies.
Describe and interpret the causes and effects of World War I and World War II on the relationship between the United States and Europe.
The Gilded Age & the Progressive Era
Identify the motivations for groups coming to the United States and discuss U.S political policies towards immigration.
The Cold War
Discuss the key people, ideas, and events of the Cold War era and analyze their impact on economic and political policy in the United States.
Analyze how international policies contributed to the end of the Cold War.
The Contemporary World
Identify and analyze trends in domestic and foreign affairs of the United States from the end of Vietnam to 9/11/2001.
Discuss the impact of conflicts on U.S. economic, political, and social position in the world, i.e., Korea, Vietnam, Persian Gulf, Iraq, and the War on Terror.
Analyze how major sources of tension or conflict influenced the current political climate in the United States, i.e., September 11th, Patriot Act, and security issues.
Describe the United States' policy concerning strategic, political, and economic interests on the Middle East, Latin America, Mexico, immigration, trade, and the environment.
Explore the influence of popular U.S. culture on the culture of other nations and vice versa.
Evaluate the influence of U.S. cultural ideas on other nations.
Explore the influence of various world cultures on the United States.
World
Describe the economic and cultural influence other nations have on the state of Nevada.
Discuss the economic, political and cultural relationships the United States has with other countries.
Middle Ages
Examine how the Crusades led to a diffusion of ideas throughout Europe and Asia.
Nevada & the World
Examine how decisions made in the settlement of the West affected modern foreign commerce, i.e., energy, mining, and multinational corporations.
Explain the significance of major news events Nevada and at the national and world levels.
Imperialism & the World Wars
Explain the impact of imperialism and colonial rule on African, Asian, and South American peoples and the resulting independence movements in Africa, Asia, and South America.
Describe the causes and effects of the Russian Revolution, i.e., Marxism, Leninism, and Bolshevism.
Discuss the causes, characteristics, and consequences of European and Japanese imperialism prior to World War II.
Analyze the causes, course, and effects of World War I and World War II on the world.
The Cold War
Describe the significance of the breakup of the USSR and the influence of the international and economic factors that contributed to the end of the Cold War.
Examine the decline of colonial rule and the development of independent nations.
Describe the rise of totalitarian societies in Europe, Asia, and Latin America.
Explain the impact of world commerce on the relationships between developed and developing nations.
Describe the contributions of the social, political, and economic characteristics of modern Latin American, African, Chinese, Indian, and Japanese civilizations.
Contemporary Global Issues
Describe tensions in contemporary Islamic countries over reconciling traditional and Western influences.
Analyze the political and religious factors that contribute to the instability in the Middle East.
Describe how political and economic alliances affect peoples and countries.
Describe how global issues such as human rights, the environment, regional conflicts, and health issues affect nations differently.
Analyze how the contemporary political climate has changed personal and national security within and among nations.

text: Content Standard G5.0 - The World in Spatial Terms: Students use maps, globes, and other geographic tools and technologies to locate and extrapolate information about people, places, and environments.

children.text: Map Elements & Concepts
Recognize that a globe is a representation of Earth and use vocabulary related to direction and location, i.e., up/down; left/right; near/far; above/beyond.
Differentiate between and identify water and land on a map and globe and use the terms ocean and continent.
Identify titles and symbols maps.
Identify and use cardinal directions on a compass rose to locate places on a map.
Differentiate between a city and a state using appropriate examples.
Identify and use intermediate directions on a compass rose to locate places on a map of Nevada.
Identify and locate major geographic features in Nevada and the United States using maps and map elements.
Use map elements, including scale, to identify and locate physical and human features in the United States and the world.
Use map elements including scale to identify and locate physical and human features in the United States and the world.
Map Selection & Analysis
Describe maps as representations of places.
Recognize the shape of North America on a world map.
Recognize spatial patterns, i.e., political units, physical features, on a map and globe.
Compare uses of maps and globes.
Identify and explain simple spatial patterns on a map, i.e., population centers, farmland, mountains.
Identify spatial patterns on a map of Nevada, i.e., deserts, mountains, population.
Identify spatial patterns of the U.S.
Describe purposes for different types of maps and globes, i.e., topographical, political, physical.
Compare characteristics and purposes of several types of maps, map projections, and other geographic representations.
Make and defend a spatial decision using basic geographic vocabulary, tools, and concepts.
Analyze and interpret geographic information by selecting appropriate maps, map projections, and other representations, i.e., urban planning, national parks.
Apply concepts and models of spatial organization and use quantitative methods to identify and make decisions about geo-graphic information.
Analyze a variety of complex maps, i.e., topographic, demographic, and land use, to acquire geographic information.
Map Construction
Use simple maps to illustrate direction.
Construct a map key from given symbols and choose a map title.
Give and follow simple oral directions to move from one location to another.
Construct a simple map including a title, symbols, and directions from a bird's eye view.
Construct a map of Nevada displaying human and physical features.
Construct maps, graphs, and charts to display information about human and physical features in the United States.
Construct mental maps from memory, i.e., sketch a map.
Create and compare maps of about human and physical features around the world for purpose, accuracy, content, form, and design.
Provide oral directions in order to move from one location to another.
Construct complex, accurate maps and models from memory to answer questions about locations of human and physical features.
Map Use & Geographic Tools
Visually display geographic information using simple lists, graphs, and maps.
Use a simple letter/number grid system to find a specific location.
Identify geographic information within media sources, i.e., maps, books, photographs.
Recognize different types of special maps, i.e., neighborhood, school, and classroom.
List careers requiring the use of geographic tools.
Utilize different types of Nevada maps, i.e., population and physical maps, to understand spatial distribution.
Identify the purpose and content of various U.S. maps.
Derive geographic information from photographs, maps, graphs, books, and technological resources.
Compare Earth's physical and human features using maps, fieldwork, graphic representations, aerial photographs, satellite images, and technological resources.
Analyze maps for purpose, accuracy, content, and design.
Analyze and interpret Earth's physical and human features using appropriate geographic tools and technologies.
Select and design maps, graphs, diagrams, tables, or charts to organize geographic information using a variety of technologies.

text: Content Standard G6.0 - Places & Regions - Students understand the physical and human features of places and use this information to define and study regions and their patterns of change.

children.text: Application of Concepts & Characteristics of Places & Regions
Identify areas that have different purposes in the home, i.e., kitchen, bedroom; or the classroom, i.e., exit door, teacher desk.
Sort and group pictures displaying geographic features, e.g. forests, deserts, lake regions.
Define region and provide examples of regions.
Describe neighborhoods and communities as places where people live, work, and play.
Distinguish between physical (natural) and human (man-made) features.
Identify characteristics of neighborhoods and communities, i.e., physical geographical differences, land use, population density.
Describe the distinguishing features of historical regions in Nevada, i.e., Native American tribal territories, pioneer trails, and settlement areas.
Identify regional changes in Nevada over time.
Provide examples of human – environment interactions in the U.S.
Identify U. S. regions in which historical events occurred, i.e., thirteen colonies, Underground Railroad, and California gold fields.
Describe physical and human features, i.e., cultural characteristics, of places and regions in Nevada, the United States, and the world.
Locate major civilizations, ancient through current, and describe how and why these regions changed over time.
Illustrate the relationship between the physical and cultural characteristics of a region.
Evaluate the role regions have played in historical events.
Define physical geographic terms, i.e., archipelago, gulf, basin, tundra.
Determine how relationships between humans and the physical environment lead to the development of and connections among places and regions.
Explain why characteristics of place change.
Apply the concept of region to organize and study a geographic issue.
Analyze selected historical issues, demographics, and questions using the geographic concept of regions.
Cultural Identity & Perspective
Describe self as a unique individual with characteristics similar to others.
Identify similarities and differences between people in the community.
Identify traditions and customs that families practice.
Identify ways people express culture.
List ways people view their own communities, i.e., a ranching community, a tourist destination.
Identify and describe the diversity and cultural traditions of Nevada's people, i.e., Native Americans, Basque communities.
Provide examples of cultural identity in communities or regions from different perspectives.
Describe relationships between regions and belief systems and tell how these are important to cultural identity.
Compare how cultural characteristics affect different points of view with regard to places and regions.
Explain why places and regions are important to cultural identity and can serve as forces for both unification and fragmentation.
Compare characteristics of places and regions from different perspectives.
Patterns of Change & Impact of Technology
Identify patterns of change within the community, i.e., construction.
Identify patterns of change in the community.
Provide examples of geographical uses of machines, tools, and technologies, i.e., surveying tools, map navigation programs.
List ways people use technology for geographic purposes, i.e., weather forecasting, use of aerial photographs to measure population changes over time.
Show how regional change in Nevada from decade to decade has affected characteristics of place, i.e., plows allow farmers to prepare the land for planting, pick axes assist in mining operations.
Show how regional change in the United States from decade to decade has affected characteristics of place, i.e., salt and sand used to melt ice, flood basins, levees.
Compare the uses of technology across world cultures.
Determine how tools affect the way cultural groups perceive and use resources within places and regions.
Location
Recall from memory the street on which s/he lives.
Identify the geographic setting of a picture or story.
Recall home address and phone number.
Show that different locations have different addresses.
Locate his/her city and state on a map.
Locate and name the states surrounding Nevada.
Identify latitude and longitude on a map or globe.
Locate the counties and county seats of Nevada.
Identify the equator, Prime Meridian, and the International Date Line.
Label a map of the United States with their capitals.
Define absolute location.
Use absolute and relative location (including latitude and longitude) to locate prominent countries, cities, and physical features in different regions of the world.
Use absolute and relative location (including latitude and longitude) to locate prominent countries, cities, and physical features in different regions of the world.

text: Content Standard G7.0 - Human Systems - Students understand how economic, political, and cultural processes interact to shape patterns of human migration and settlement, influence and interdependence, and conflict and cooperation.

children.text: Demographic Concepts
Use the classroom population to categorize simple demographic information.
Construct a visual model, i.e., graph, table, and/or choropleth map of population distribution.
Compare population distribution across regions using maps and mathematical representations, i.e., tables and graphs.
Describe differences in population distribution within Nevada regions.
Explain differences in population distribution within the United States.
Describe characteristics of developing and developed countries using demographic concepts.
Analyze demographic trends in the world.
Migration & Settlement
Explain that people move from one location to another.
Explain that some people live in locations other than where they were born.
Categorize different ways to move people, goods, and ideas, i.e., air, water, land, phone, and/or computer.
Identify transportation and communication networks.
List examples of movements of people, goods, and ideas into and across Nevada.
List push-pull factors influencing human migration and settlement in the United States.
Describe how movements of people, goods, ideas, and resources have affected events and conditions in the past and present.
Identify the conditions necessary for the development of civilizations and the cultural, political, and economic characteristics resulting from the growth of civilizations.
Evaluate the impact of migration and settlement on physical and human systems.
Analyze the development of civilizations and the impact it has on the changes and progress of human development.
Rural & Urban Communities
Identify characteristics of rural and urban communities.
Define and compare rural and urban communities.
List reasons why people choose to live in urban or rural communities.
Describe differences among rural, suburban, and urban settlement in Nevada.
Describe differences among rural, suburban, and urban settlement in the United States.
Identify patterns of rural and urban settlements in developing and developed countries.
Compare characteristics and patterns of rural and urban migration and settlement in developing and developed countries.
Evaluate why major cities develop in particular geographic locations and how this affects cultures.
Analysis of Economic Issues
Use a map to display information about an economic product.
Describe historical and current economic issues in Nevada using geographic resources, i.e., illustrate demographic changes due to mining and gaming.
Describe historical and current economic issues in the U.S. using geographic resources, i.e., illustrate demographic changes due to mining and gaming.
Identify a regional or international economic issue and explain it from a spatial perspective.
Explain how the physical and human geography of regions influences their allocation of resources.
Analyze and evaluate international economic issues from a spatial perspective.
Analyze how location and distance connect to influence economic systems at local, national, and international levels.
Human Organizations
List types of social groups to which people belong.
Describe purposes for various organizations.
Describe why types of organizations may differ by geographic region in Nevada.
Describe why types of organizations may differ by geographic region in the U.S.
Compare cultural, political, and economic organizations in the United States.
Evaluate changes in the size and structure of cultural, political, and economic organizations.

text: Content Standard G8.0 - Environment and Society - Students understand effects of interactions between human and physical systems and the changes in use, distribution, and importance of resources.

children.text: Changes in the Physical Environment
Recognize weather changes with the seasons and how people adapt to those changes.
Tell how the physical environment affects activity at school, i.e., inside/outside recess.
Tell how the physical environment affects community activity, i.e., recreation, water usage.
Predict possible geographic changes that could take place in the neighborhood or community.
Describe ways physical environments affect human activity in Nevada using historical and contemporary examples.
Describe ways physical environments affect human activity in the United States using historical and contemporary examples.
Describe and predict the regional and global impact of changes in the physical environment.
Analyze how changes in the physical environment can increase or diminish its capacity to support human activity.
Technology & Modifications of the Physical Environment
Provide examples of tools that assist in finding geographic locations.
Identify how people shape the physical environment.
List tools, machines, or technologies that people have used to change the physical environment.
Compare ways people modify the physical environment.
Describe how technologies altered the physical environment in Nevada, and the effects of those changes on its people.
Explore the impact of human modification of Nevada's physical environment on the people who live there.
Describe how technologies altered the physical environment in the U.S., and the effects of those changes on its people.
Explore the impact of human modification of the United States' physical environment on the people who live there.
Evaluate the role of technology in the human modification of the physical environment.
Describe the changes that result from human modification of the physical environment.
Describe the ways in which technology has affected the human capacity to modify the physical environment and evaluate possible regional and global impact.
Develop possible responses to changes caused by human modification of the physical environment.
Effects of Natural Hazards on Human Systems
Define and provide examples of natural hazards.
Identify people, groups, and organizations that respond to natural hazards.
Identify natural hazards in Nevada and their impact on the population.
Identify and locate potential natural hazards in the United States and their impacts on the land and population.
Discuss the impact of natural hazards on the use and distribution of resources.
Research a specific natural hazard and document its effects on human systems.
Analyze human perception and reaction to natural hazards including use, distribution, and importance of resources.
Management of Earth's Resources
Identify locations for accessing basic resources available to the student, i.e., food, water.
Identify natural resources and where they can be found in the neighborhood.
Describe ways humans depend on and manage natural resources within their communities.
Describe the distribution patterns of natural resources in Nevada.
Describe and compare the distribution patterns and use of natural resources in the United States.
Define renewable, nonrenewable, and human resources.
Categorize and locate examples of renewable, nonrenewable, and human resources.
Evaluate different viewpoints regarding a resource.
Analyze patterns of use, the changing distribution, and relative importance of Earth's resources.
Develop policies for the use and management of Earth's resources that consider the various interests involved.

text: Content Standard E9.0 - The Market Economy - Students will understand how scarcity and incentives affect choices, how markets work, why markets form, how supply and demand interact to determine the market price, and how changes in prices act as economic signals to coordinate trade.

children.text: Incentives, Choice and Cost
Show that resources are scarce, such as a limited number of crayons.
Give examples of all-or-nothing choices, such as choosing to have music on or off.
Give examples of what is given up when choices are made.
Identify needs as high priority wants, and wants as goods, services, or leisure activities.
Give examples of incentives and determine whether they are positive or negative.
Describe how scarcity requires a person to make a choice and identify costs associated with that choice.
Discuss choices made by individuals including the concepts of opportunity cost and total benefit.

Analyze choices and incentive systems used by parents, teachers, employers and government using the concepts of:
  • Total benefits and opportunity costs
  • Impact of marginal costs and marginal benefits
  • Effectiveness
Consumers
Identify a consumer.
Identify consumers and where they make purchases.
Give examples of prices consumers have paid when buying goods and services.
Give reasons why consumers choose to buy more of a good or service, i.e., when prices are low, and when they choose to buy less, and when prices are high.
Demonstrate an understanding that an individual can be a consumer and producer at the same time.

Identify factors that affect purchasing decisions such as:
  • Price
  • Income
  • Availability of substitutes
  • Self interest
Analyze how consumers adjust their purchases in response to price changes using the concept of price elasticity.
Producers
Identify a producer.
Identify producers in your neighborhood and community.
Give examples of prices set by businesses for selling goods and services.
Give reasons why producers choose to sell more of a good or service, i.e., when a price is high, and when they choose to sell less, and when its price is low.
Identify the resources needed for production in households, schools, and community groups.

Identify factors that affect producers' decisions to supply goods such as:
  • Output prices
  • Input prices
  • Technology
Assess how producers might adjust their sales decisions in response to price changes using the concept of price elasticity.
Employees
Identify jobs in the community.
Give examples of ways people earn money.
Discuss why people work.
Demonstrate an understanding of income and give examples.
Identify factors within an individual's control that can affect the likelihood of employment.
Describe how income reflects choices people make about education, training, skill development, lifestyle, and careers.

Discuss career paths considering:
  • Specific skills required
  • Wages
  • Impact of skills on wages

Evaluate career paths considering:
  • Specific skills required
  • Wages
  • Impact of skills on wages
  • Response of wages to market demand
Markets & Prices
Explain why all those who trade must benefit from the trade, using an example such as trading lunch items.
Demonstrate an understanding of supply and demand in a market.
Demonstrate and explain an understanding of supply and demand in a market, i.e., law of supply and law of demand.

Analyze markets using the concepts of supply and demand, including:
  • Impact of changes in supply on prices
  • Impact of changes in demand on prices
  • Impact of price controls

text: Content Standard E10.0 - The U.S. Economy As A Whole - Students will identify indicators used to measure economic performance, understand key aspects of how the economy acts as a system, and understand the roles of money, interest rates, savers, and borrowers, financial institutions, and the central bank in our economy.

children.text: Forms & Functions of Money
Identify United States currency.
Explain what money is and how it is used.
Discuss the concept that money is limited.
Identify forms of money used by people across time and place.
Discuss how the discovery of silver in Nevada affected the forms of money in circulation.
Define trade and commodities used in trade.
Describe the transition from the use of commodities as money to the use of modern forms of money.
Illustrate how prices stated in money terms help people compare the value of products.
Describe the nation's current money supply measures, including M1 and M2.
Explain the three functions of money: medium of exchange, store of value, unit of account.
Interest, Saving Borrowing
Identify reasons for saving money.
Define banking terms, including saving, interest, and borrowing.
Identify instances in which people might pay interest or receive interest.
Identify how interest rates affect borrowing, saving, and purchasing using credit.
Explain why riskier loans command higher interest rates than safer loans.
Identify the pros and cons of paying with cash versus using credit.
Explain why a real interest rate accurately measures the benefit of saving or the cost of borrowing, and indicate ways a high interest rate could be detrimental or beneficial.
Explain what a credit rating is and how it affects access to loans.
Financial Institutions
Identify reasons people use banks.
Discuss reasons people use banks.
Identify services offered by different types financial institutions.
Compare the rewards and risks of saving money in financial institutions.
Compare the risks and rewards of using the services offered by different financial institutions.
Circular Flow
Illustrate how one person's spending becomes another person's income.
Explain the circular flow of economic activity.
Explain how the circular flow can affect the nation's income.
Economic Growth
Define productive resources.
Recognize the three types of productive resources.
Explain how the current utilization of a productive resource affects the availability of that resource in the future.
Analyze the potential production of goods and services for a nation as determined by its resources and technology.
Inflation
Define inflation and deflation.
Explain how inflation affects individuals as they use their incomes to buy goods and services.
Explain how the Federal Reserve influences bank loans, the economy's inflation rate, and economic activity in general, using the reserve requirement, discount rate, and open market operations.
Unemployment
Define labor force and unemployment.
Identify factors that can affect an individual's likelihood of being unemployed, and give examples of the costs of unemployment to the economy as a whole.
Explain how government fiscal policy may affect the rate of unemployment by influencing production, employment, and price levels.
Per Capita Measures
Define per capita.
Demonstrate per capita measures in the classroom.
Determine per capita GDP using data on population and GDP for several countries then compare with the United States.
Describe how U.S. living standards have changed over time using real GDP per capita as a measure of the standard of living.
Economic Performance Indicators
Explain gross domestic product (GDP) and how it is used to describe a country's economic output.
Compare the buying power of the U.S. dollar in one year with its buying power in another year using the consumer price index (CPI).
Distinguish between a high rate and a low rate of unemployment for the U.S. economy over time.
Define recession and examine the U.S. economy over time using the change in real GDP.
Discuss the effects of inflation on the U.S. economy using the consumer price index.
Compare the unemployment rates for groups of people who differ by age, sex, ethnicity, occupation, and education.
Demonstrate knowledge of when, why, and how interest rate levels have experienced relative highs and relative lows throughout U.S. history.
Financial Institutions, Credit, & Interest Rates
Explain the purposes and functions of financial institutions by comparing and contrasting the services, and evaluate the risks and rewards to borrowers and savers.
Explain how interest rates are determined using supply and demand.

text: Content Standard E11.0 - The Dynamic Economy - Students will identify the causes of economic change; explain how the U.S. economic system responds to those changes; and explain how other economic systems respond to change.

children.text: Organizations
Identify a for-profit and a not-for-profit organization in the community and a service each provides.
Explain the purposes for establishing for-profit and not-for-profit organizations.
Describe for-profit and not-for-profit organizations and explain why not-for-profit organizations are tax exempt.

Identify the roles of organizations in a market economy, including:
  • For-profit organizations
  • Not-for-profit organizations
  • Labor unions
Investment
Provide an example of how purchasing a tool or acquiring education can increase the ability to produce goods.
Explain how investment in either physical capital or human capital improves standards of living by increasing productivity.
Analyze the past, present, and future role of investment in enhancing economic growth and raising living standards.
Entrepreneurship
Identify businesses in the community.
Identify and explain what business owners do.
Define entrepreneur and identify those individuals in Nevada.
Describe the steps an entrepreneur would take to start a business.
Determine the advantages and disadvantages of being an entrepreneur.
Evaluate how entrepreneurs affect the economy by solving problems, taking risks, and taking advantage of opportunities to earn profits.
Specialization & Interdependence
Explain why specialization increases productivity and interdependence.
Give examples of how specialization is facilitated by trade.
Judge the pros and cons of specialization and interdependence.
Competition
Describe what it means to compete, and give examples of ways sellers compete.
Illustrate how competition among sellers decreases prices, while competition among buyers increases prices.
Explain how individual self-interest, channeled through the marketplace, can increase the overall standard of living.
Role of Government

Identify the role of government in a market economy regarding:
  • Public goods
  • Externalities
  • Monopoly power
  • Redistribution of income
  • Definition and protection of property rights

Analyze the role of government in a market economy regarding:
  • Public goods
  • externalities
  • Monopoly power
  • Redistribution of income
  • Definition and protection of property rights
Rise of Democratic Capitalism
Define mercantilism.
Discuss the rise of the merchant class, the development of mercantilism and the move toward industrialization.
Describe the rise of national economies, the emergence of free markets and democratic capitalism.
Comparative Systems

Define stereotypical economic systems by contrasting:
  • capitalism and socialism
  • command economy and market economy

Illustrate the idea that real world economies tend to be mixed economies containing elements of:
  • capitalism
  • socialism
  • command allocations of resources
  • market allocations of resources
Resource Allocation
Make decisions involving classroom resources.
Identify resources that are shared in the classroom and the community.
Describe ways to share classroom resources.
Identify classroom resources that are limited and must be shared.
Describe resources that are limited in Nevada and ways in which resources are shared.
Identify scarce resources and identify how they are allocated in the United States.
Explain ways in which households, schools, or community groups allocate resources.
Explain how consumer and producer reactions to price changes affect resource allocation.
Compare the benefits and costs of allocating resources through markets or government.
Discuss how an economy's price system determines what goods and services will be produced, how they will be produced, and who will receive them.

text: Content Standard E12.0 - The International Economy - Students will explore trends in international trade, the impact of trade on the U.S. economy, and the role of exchange rates.

children.text: International Interdependence
Define trade.
Demonstrate an understanding of trade by providing an example.
Differentiate between barter and monetary trade.
Define imports and exports.
Explain why the U.S. imports and exports goods.
Describe how the exchange of goods and services around the world creates interdependence among people in different countries and effects standards of living.
Describe how the economic characteristics of other countries and their economic events affect the United States.
Exchange Rates
Define exchange rates.
Explain how a change in the exchange rate affects purchasing power.
Determine how a change in exchange rates affects the ability of residents of one country to consume products from other countries.
Globalization
Identify goods that would not be readily available in Nevada without international trade.
Define globalization and explain how the U.S. economy is affected by international trade.
Describe the rise of international economies, the emergence of capitalism and free markets around the world.
Assess the impact of globalization on the U.S. and world economies.
Restricted Trade
Explain how governments use tariffs or quotas to restrict trade.
Analyze the pros and cons of international trade, comparing free trade with restricted trade.

text: Content Standard C13.0 - Citizenship and the Law - Students know why society needs rules, laws, and government and understand the roles, rights, and responsibilities of citizens.

children.text: Rules & Law
Identify and follow classroom and school rules that guide behavior and resolve conflicts.
Identify and follow classroom and school rules that guide behavior and resolve conflicts.
Identify and follow classroom and school rules that guide behavior and resolve conflicts.
Identify and discuss examples of rules, laws, and authorities that keep people safe and property secure.
Identify and discuss examples of rules, laws, and authorities that keep people safe and property secure in the state of Nevada.
Explain that the Declaration of Independence, the U.S. Constitution, and the Bill of Rights, are written documents that are the foundation of the United States government.
Explain the difference between the rule of law and the rule of man, i.e., divine right of monarchs, dictatorships.
Identify major conflicts in social, political, and economic life and analyze the role of compromise in the resolution of these issues.
Describe the significance of the Declaration of Independence and the U.S. Constitution as foundations of U.S. democracy.
Describe how the Nevada and U.S. Constitution serve as devices for preserving state and national principles and as vehicles for change, including the amendment process.
Explain the concept of the rule of law in the establishment of the U.S. Constitution.
Analyze major conflicts in social, political, and economic life and evaluate the role of compromise in the resolution of these issues.
Describe the historic influences of ideas, i.e., Greek law, Magna Carta, Iroquois League, Social Contract Theory, Natural Rights Philosophy, and Republicanism on the creation of early U.S. documents.
Describe how the Nevada and U.S. Constitution serve as devices for preserving state and national principles and as vehicles for change, including the formal and informal amendment processes.
Rights
Identify an individual's rights within the classroom.
Identify an individual's rights within the classroom.
Identify an individual's rights within the classroom and in school.
Discuss that democracy involves voting, majority rule, and setting rules.
Explain that democracy involves voting, majority rule, and setting rules.
Describe the operation of representative government.
Explain the influence of ancient civilizations of the roles, rights, and responsibilities of citizens.
Explain the necessity of the protection of individual rights in a democratic society.

Analyze the United States Constitution and its amendments in protecting individual rights, including the Fourteenth Amendment's provisions for due process and equal protection of in-dividual rights through the examination of landmark cases, i.e.,
  • Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka
  • Gideon v. Wainwright
  • Miranda v. Arizona
  • Tinker v. Des Moines Independent Community School District
Examine the rights of citizens and how these rights are protected and restricted.
Responsibilities
Recognize individual choices.
Participate in class decision-making, i.e., individual responsibilities in the classroom and school.
Participate in class decision-making, i.e., individual responsibilities in the classroom.
Explain individual responsibilities in the classroom and the school.
Describe the criteria for Nevada citizenship.
Describe the criteria for U.S. citizenship.
Define and explain popular sovereignty and the need for citizen involvement at all levels of U.S. government.

Identify and explain the rights, privileges, and responsibilities associated with Nevada and U.S. citizenship, including voting, holding office, jury duty, and military service, community service, and public service.
Analyze and evaluate the role of citizen participation in civic life.
Examine the responsibilities of local, state, and national citizenship.
Symbols
Recognize the Pledge of Allegiance.
Name a traditional U.S. patriotic activity, holiday, or symbol.
Recognize the Pledge of Allegiance.
Name a traditional U.S. patriotic activity, holiday, or symbol.
Recognize the Pledge of Allegiance.
Describe traditional patriotic activities, holidays, or symbols from around the world.
Recognize the Pledge of Allegiance and discuss its purpose.
Explain why we have patriotic activities, holidays, and symbols.
Discuss the symbolic importance of the Pledge of Allegiance.
Explain why we celebrate Nevada Day.
Explain the symbolic importance of the Pledge of Allegiance and the Fourth of July.
Explain the significance of mottoes and symbols to the cultural and political identity of various societies.
Interpret the symbols and documents of a nation and analyze how they represent its identity.

text: Content Standard C14.0 - The Federal System: U.S., State, and Local Governments - Students understand the U.S. Constitution and the government it creates, including the relationship between national and sub-national governments, as well as the structure and function of state and local governments.

children.text: Federalism
Describe the relationship between classroom and school rules.
Describe examples of national, state, and local laws.
Define federalism.
Give examples of governmental powers, i.e., the power to tax, declare war, and issue drivers' licenses, that are distributed between the national and state governments.
Explain how the supremacy clause of the U.S. Constitution defines the relationship between national and state governments.
Explain the purpose of a tribal government.
Explain the U.S. Constitutional provisions for division of powers between the national and state governments (delegated, implied, reserved, concurrent powers).
Analyze and give examples of the expansion of the national government through the application of enumerated powers and implied powers.
Provide contemporary examples of federalism. Compare and contrast the structure of the Nevada and United States Constitutions.
Use examples to illustrate the supremacy clause in defining the relationship between state and national governments.
Describe the unique role of tribal and territorial governments in the U.S.
Governmental Structures
Name the current President of the United States.
Name the current President of the United States.
Name the current President of the United States.
Name the current mayor of the town.
Name the current President of the United States.
Name the current governor of Nevada
Explain why local governments are created.
Name the three branches of state government.
Understand the role of courts.
Identify the three branches of government (as set forth in the U.S. Constitution).
Name the two houses of the U.S. Congress and explain how representation is determined.
Identify the powers of the U.S. Congress, i.e., power to tax, declare war, and impeach the President.
Identify the duties of the President within the executive branch.
Explain that the U.S. Supreme Court is the highest court in the land.
Describe the purpose of a judge and jury in a trial as it relates to resolving disputes.
Explain the functions of the three branches of government (executive, legislative, and judicial) as found in the U.S. and Nevada Constitutions.
Explain the system of checks and balances and the principle of limited powers in the design of the U.S. Constitution.
Explain the organization and function of State and local government.
Explain the historic compromises that created a two-house Congress and identify the responsibilities of each house.
Describe powers of the U.S. Congress.
Describe the duties of the President and other executive officials.
Describe the function of the U.S. Supreme Court including judicial review using landmark court cases.
Identify the state and local judicial processes, i.e., juvenile, civil, and criminal court systems.
Examine the organization of the U.S. Constitution and describe the structure it creates, including the executive, legislative, and judicial branches.
Examine the organization of the Nevada Constitution and describe the structure it creates, including the executive, legislative, and judicial branches.
Explain the structure and function of local governments.
Analyze the effectiveness of checks and balances in maintaining the equal division of power.
Describe the creation of laws through the legislative process.

Describe the duties of the executive branch, including:
  • Cabinet/departments
  • Regulatory commissions
  • Executive Office of the President/White House staff
Describe the structure and jurisdiction of the federal court system and analyze the power of judicial review.
Explain the state and local judicial processes such as juvenile, civil, and criminal court systems.

text: Content Standard C15.0 - The Political Process - Students describe the roles of political parties, elections, interest groups, media, and public opinion in the democratic process.

children.text: Elections & Leadership
List the qualities of a leader.
Describe the qualities of a leader.
Explain the qualities of a leadership.
Name the two major political parties.
Describe the election process.
Provide examples of how political parties have changed.
Assess the processes by which leaders are selected in the U.S. political system and analyze the role of the Electoral College system in the election of the President.
Analyze the role and function of political parties in public policy and the electoral process.
Formation of Public Opinion
Identify sources of information
Identify sources of information
Discuss why people form groups
Introduce sources of information people use to form an opinion.
Define and give examples of state and local interest groups.
Identify sources of information people use to form an opinion.
Give examples of national interest groups.
Compare sources of information people use to form an opinion.
Define propaganda and give examples.
Identify the impact of interest groups and public opinion on the political process.
Identify the influence of the media in forming public opinion.
Identify propaganda and persuasion in political advertising and literature.
Provide examples of contemporary public issues that may require public solutions.
Evaluate the significance of interest groups and public opinion in the political process of a democratic society.
Analyze the role of the media in the process of political persuasion.
Evaluate propaganda in the political process.
Describe the process by which public policy is formulated and implemented.

text: Content Standard C16.0 - Global Relations - Students explain the different political systems in the world and how those systems relate to the United States and its citizens.

children.text: Global Relations
Name their school.
Name their school.
Name their school and community.
Identify their city, state, and country.
Identify their county, city, state, and country.
Describe the influences other nations have had on the development of the United States political system.

Define the characteristics of a country:
  • Sovereignty
  • Territory
  • Population
  • Organized government

Define the world's major political systems:
  • Monarchy
  • Totalitarian dictatorship
  • Democratic systems
    • presidential systems
    • parliamentary systems
  • Socialism
  • Communism
Identify nations that play a significant role in U.S. foreign policy.
Define foreign policy and describe ways nations interact diplomatically, i.e., treaties, trade, humanitarian aid, and military intervention.
List and describe international organizations, i.e., the United Nations, World Bank, Amnesty International, and the International Red Cross.

Summarize and evaluate the significant characteristics of the world's major political systems:
  • Monarchy
  • Totalitarian dictatorship
  • Democratic systems
    • presidential systems
    • parliamentary systems
  • Socialism
  • Communism
Analyze the conflict between U.S. policies of isolationism versus intervention in world affairs.
Identify and analyze U.S. foreign policy in dealing with international issues, i.e., diplomacy, economic policy, humanitarian aid, and military intervention.
Critique the role of international organizations, i.e., the United Nations, World Bank, Amnesty International, and the International Red Cross.
